caption_original:
Looking for a way to contribute to conservation? Citizen scientists play an important role in many of our monitoring programs and provide biologists with invaluable information. 

While on a recent vacation to Cuba, nature photographer and citizen scientist, Alan Chaplin, did not know the Piping Plover he was snapping photos of was extraordinary. He reported the band only to discover that this bird had outlived its average lifespan by more than 4 times! 

The 17-year old plover was spotted near the same location our biologists banded it in 2000. It bred on Cavendish Beach in Prince Edward Island National Park in the early 2000s but had not been reported in over a decade. This resight is extremely useful for our scientists in understanding this at-risk species. 

Piping Plover continue to be marked in Canada, now with uniquely coded leg flags. For information on how to report a banded Piping Plover: http://ow.ly/8cAr3090oBx

He reported the band only to discover that this bird had outlived its average lifespan by more than times! The -year old plover was spotted near the same location our biologists banded it in . It bred on Cavendish Beach in Prince Edward Island National Park in the early s but had not been reported in over a decade. This resight is extremely useful for our scientists in understanding this at-risk species. Piping Plover continue to be marked in Canada, now with uniquely coded leg flags. caption_original:
Dive into Canada’s newest Marine Protected Area: the Hecate Strait and Queen Charlotte Sound Glass Sponge Reefs.
 
In the deep, cold waters of Hecate Strait and Queen Charlotte Sound, British Columbia, Canada, beautiful creatures – glass sponges – create a vibrant and unique reef ecosystem. This Marine Protected Area is helping to safeguard the globally unique and important aquatic environment that provides key habitats for marine wildlife.

This Marine Protected Area is helping to safeguard the globally unique and important aquatic environment that provides key habitats for marine wildlife.

Martine works at Environment and Climate Change Canada as a geomatics technician, providing technical and scientific support to her biologist colleagues.

Whether validating critical habitat of a species at risk or the land cover of a given region, her work is concrete and the projects varied. It’s a stimulating job that involves using the latest technologies to improve the quality of our environment. #WomenScienceDay

caption_original:
Shirley is an applied ecology technician at Environment and Climate Change Canada. Her work involves planning and conducting several types of aerial waterfowl surveys, including monitoring breeding pairs in the spring, Barrow’s Goldeneye in winter and the Common Eider at various times of year. 

She also takes part in duck and goose banding operations, which gives her a chance to travel to various locations in Quebec. Her work involves flying in helicopters at low altitudes with a lot of changes in direction (not for the queasy!).

What she loves about her job is the combination of field and office work. Her advice to women who are interested: take the time to find a career where you can combine your interests, abilities and values. #WomenScienceDay

Her advice to women who are interested: take the time to find a career where you can combine your interests, abilities and values.

caption_original:
Hunters: what do you think about the proposed changes to the Migratory Birds Regulations? 

1) The Government of Canada would discontinue the issuance of bait authorizations; 
2) The Government of Canada would prohibit the deliberate modification of an agricultural crop for the purpose of attracting migratory birds for hunting. For example, intentionally flooding a standing cornfield.

The consultation period ends on February 17. Take a look at the consultation document and share your feedback! http://ow.ly/h3C9308Qb4k

For example, intentionally flooding a standing cornfield. The consultation period ends on February . Take a look at the consultation document and share your feedback!

caption_original:
Happy #WorldWetlandsDay! Canadian wetlands provide enormous benefits to people by protecting against floods, improving water quality and water supply, controlling erosion and supporting a variety of recreational activities. 

Although the importance of wetlands is being recognized more and more; many of Canada’s wetlands in settled areas have been lost, and Canada continues to lose these important habitats – both naturally and because of human-related activities.

The National Wetland Conservation Fund (NWCF) supports organizations and communities across Canada to participate actively in the restoration and enhancement of degraded wetlands. For example, an NWCF project led by Ducks Unlimited Canada enhanced 140 hectares of wetland habitat throughout N.B., N.S. and P.E.I. 

Find out more about NWCF: http://ow.ly/ZE4W308C2Am

caption_original:
Do you want to know more about air pollutants in your province? We just released Canada’s 2017 Air Pollutant Emission Inventory (APEI). It’s a comprehensive inventory of emissions of 17 air pollutants from different emissions sources, at the national, provincial and territorial levels.

Why should you care? Because air pollution can hurt your health by irritating the lungs, reducing lung function, and increasing susceptibility to allergens in people with asthma.

Air pollution also hurts the environment by reducing the growth and productivity of some crops and injuring flowers, shrubs and forests.

And economically, air pollution hurts us by increasing health care costs, missed days of work and reduced worker productivity, costing the Canadian economy billions of dollars per year. http://ow.ly/7sJW3094pNI
caption_cleaned: Do you want to know more about air pollutants in your province? We just released Canada’s Air Pollutant Emission Inventory (APEI). It’s a comprehensive inventory of emissions of air pollutants from different emissions sources, at the national, provincial and territorial levels. Why should you care? Because air pollution can hurt your health by irritating the lungs, reducing lung function, and increasing susceptibility to allergens in people with asthma. Air pollution also hurts the environment by reducing the growth and productivity of some crops and injuring flowers, shrubs and forests. And economically, air pollution hurts us by increasing health care costs, missed days of work and reduced worker productivity, costing the Canadian economy billions of dollars per year.

caption_original:
Did you know for more than 60 years, Canada and the United States have conducted a large-scale banding program on the Canadian Prairies? 

Each August, biologists from Canadian Wildlife Service and U.S. Fish and Wildlife work together to band thousands of birds prior to their annual migration as part of the Western Canada Cooperative Waterfowl Banding Program. Last Mountain Lake Migratory Bird Sanctuary is one of 12 sites where the banding takes place. 

Ducks flying south from Canada to the U.S. and beyond are tracked through reports to the Canadian Wildlife Service Bird Banding Office and the U.S. Geological Survey. Reports of banded bird encounters help document their longevity, movements and sources of mortality. This data helps scientists better understand migratory birds, determine appropriate regulations and ultimately contribute to their survival.

Each August, biologists from Canadian Wildlife Service and U.S. Fish and Wildlife work together to band thousands of birds prior to their annual migration as part of the Western Canada Cooperative Waterfowl Banding Program. Last Mountain Lake Migratory Bird Sanctuary is one of sites where the banding takes place. Ducks flying south from Canada to the U.S. and beyond are tracked through reports to the Canadian Wildlife Service Bird Banding Office and the U.S. Geological Survey. Reports of banded bird encounters help document their longevity, movements and sources of mortality. This data helps scientists better understand migratory birds, determine appropriate regulations and ultimately contribute to their survival.

On Friday, December 9, 2016, the Pan-Canadian Framework on Clean Growth and Climate Change was adopted.

This historic achievement for Canada represents Canada’s first ever federal, provincial and territorial plan to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, grow the economy and build resilience to a changing climate.

It puts Canada on a pathway to meet its 2030 target and fulfil our global commitment under the Paris Agreement. 

Way to go Canada! 🇨🇦 http://ow.ly/x49p3096sib

The next issue of the Quarterly Climate Impacts and Outlook: Gulf of Maine Region is now available online! 

This publication offers a binational overview of the latest season’s significant weather, water and climate events and impacts as well as an outlook for the upcoming quarter. This Canada-US climate quarterly newsletter is produced jointly with our partners from the National Oceanic Atmospheric Administration.

caption_original:
Current Ecological Gifts stretch across every region of southern Canada and make a big contribution to creating a network of protected areas! These donations help to protect Canada’s natural heritage for future generations.

The Kofman Moose Bay Ecological Gift in the O’Donnell Point Natural Area in the Georgian Bay Littoral UNESCO Biosphere Reserve is a great example! The area is home to five reptilian species at risk. By accepting donations of ecologically sensitive land, the Georgian Bay Land Trust helps to protect rare habitats and conserve Canada’s biodiversity.

 http://ow.ly/knYk309iwtL
